content.description:
Start on a thin vein of ice that goes up to a small roof, traverse left under the roof until you are under a right facing overhanging corner with an old fixed pin high up on it.
Clip the pin (also a good nut placement here if you don't want to trust the pin) and fire through the overhang moving right into the chimney.
Stem and grovel your way up the chimney cutting left onto the face wherever it makes sense for easier climbing and then right back into the chimney to find the occasional place to place pro.
Finish at the top after a FULL 60 meters to a 2 bolt bolted anchor with rap rings on the left.

Make sure to use double ropes as the line does wander with the traverse and doing it with a single and tag line wouldn't work due to rope drag.

Very fun but committing single pitch climb, be aware that you may be stuck in a corner with your last piece of pro a significant distance below you. Full alpine feel.

Easily visible from the highway on Mt Stephen between Super Bock and Twisted, park either on the highway or on the shoulder at the start of Yoho Valley Road. Cross the highway and the frozen river and slog straight up the gully underneath the climb. 45 minutes to an 1.5 hours depending on conditions.
A bunch of stubbies if there is enough ice, and a selection of nuts and cams to 2", although a 4" cam and some pitons might be useful in the chimney on lower ice years.

First pitch is the crux/money pitch. Several options, the sustained vertical line on the left would probably be closer to WI4+. After the initial ice section, it will level out. You can anchor and bring up you follower(s) or continue up through another section of ice until you hit a snowfield. Traverse left around the snow and make your way up to good ice for anchoring (will need a 70 meter rope to make it in one go). Gentler ice climbing follows for next pitch to a wooded area to anchor. Rap down route around trees, then v-thread to come down to the ground (2x ropes necessary to come down in 2x raps). 



Roughly 1 km east along the train tracks in Field, BC (park at the rail junction before crossing into town). Watch out for trains (although they move slowly near town) , try to stay on the north side of the tracks as it has more space to walk. Walk though an opening and up towards Mount Stephen (you will see an avy path) that you follow up for roughly 300 meters to the obvious start of WI4 Massey's! 

17 cm ice screws, a 21 cm to v-thread.

1st Pitch: Climb a short WI3 flow up through the rock arch and belay off of a mixture of fixed pins and a bolt.

(Continue up a snow ramp and belay on the left main ice flow)

2nd Pitch: Climb a long pitch over two steep WI4 curtains (A 60 meter rope doesn't quite reach the base of the steeper WI5 pillar so either bring 70's or do a short pitch to move the belay up into a cave on the left side of the flow)

3rd Pitch: Climb the steep WI5 pitch all the way to the top. A groove can form on the right side of this pitch which allows for stemming and significantly easier climbing.

Two full 60 meter rappels brings you down to the base of the 2nd pitch, scramble back down to the rock arch and do one more rap to the base of the route.

The route is located on Mt. Stephen and the top two pitches can be easily seen from the road. Park at the chain up area off of the highway and cross the river or alternatively park in field and traverse across the railroad tracks. It is extremely important to note that as soon as you leave the railroad and start heading up the gulley towards the base of the route, you are in avy terrain. Carry beacon shovel probe etc. and check the bulletin before you go!!! 
Screws and cord for V-threads

For years a thin ice and mixed route, Twisted has been coming in more as an ice route in recent years. The relatively short approach and great climbing make Twisted a popular objective. There is avalanche hazard on the approach and from above so check conditions.

P1, 35m: Climb WI3 ice on the right to the snow ledge, traverse left to a collection of old pins under a rock roof. Belay from here and back up the pins.

P2: 55m: Climb technical and steep WI4-5+ ice to a ledge with a great ice belay stance to the right.

P3: 20m: Climb up the narrow gully of WI4 with rock on either side to a decent ice belay under a big boulder. Some parties belay off the steel cable a bit further up but it might be an awkward belay.

Twisted is the left-most route on Mt. Stephen, and located on a prominent buttress easily visible on the left when coming down the hill into Field. Park in the lot at the bottom of the hill. Follow the trail to the highway, cross the bridge and head up to the tracks. Cross the tracks (don't touch the avalanche warning wires), and head up the slope, and then traverse to the base of the route.
Bring a standard mixed rack when it comes in thin, screws when it's fat. Descend from v-threads.

Mt. Stephen is home to a number of classic ice and mixed lines, and lies just east of the community of Field.  It is first on the left as one enters the broad valley from the east, where the community of Field is located. A couple of rail tunnels on the east end of the mountain help identify it. Routes are highly exposed to avalanche hazard both from above and below, they face a bit north of west, and are easily visible from the highway.
